Market, bridge bombings kill dozens in Iraq





Bombings in Baghdad and Karbala killed at least 56 people and wounded 78 more
Saturday morning, police and medical officials said.





FULL STORY

North Korea disarmament deadline slips





The U.S. envoy to North Korea's nuclear talks said Saturday that a
two-month-old disarmament plan lacks "momentum" as North Korea failed to meet
a deadline for shutting down its main nuclear reactor and processing facility.

Plains get snow, Texas gets tornado as storm moves east





A severe storm dropped nearly a foot of snow on parts of the central Plains
Friday and spawned at least one tornado in Texas, where one death was blamed
on high winds.

Marines to deploy tilt-rotor aircraft to Iraq





The military's controversial V-22 Osprey tilt-rotor aircraft will head to Iraq
for its first combat tour later this year, Marine officials announced Friday.

Wildfire brings destruction to Beverly Hills





Fires erupted in the hills above Los Angeles on Thursday, damaging or
destroying several homes as dangerous north winds fueled the flames. Farther
inland, a blinding sandstorm triggered a deadly highway pileup.





FULL STORY
      WATCH VIDEO
















Principal, teacher quit after sex video surfaces





A principal and a teacher at a suburban elementary school quit amid
allegations they were caught on video having sex in the principal's office,
authorities say.





FULL STORY
















Cheney plane undamaged in collision with bird





Air Force Two carrying Vice President Dick Cheney struck a bird as the plane
neared O'Hare International Airport on Friday.

Kasparov held at Russian demo





Russian chess champion and opposition activist Garry Kasparov has been
detained by police in Moscow as he tried to attend a banned protest march, his
aide told Reuters on Saturday.

Hope fades for 5 missing from capsized ship





Rescuers said Friday they had all but given up hope of finding five crewmen
alive after their ship capsized off northern Scotland.

U.S.: Al Qaeda in Iraq 'probably' tied to bombing





A U.S. Army commander on Friday said authorities still can't verify who bombed
the Iraqi parliament complex on Thursday, but al Qaeda in Iraq probably was
involved.

Gaming sting nets judge, prosecutor, Carnival organizer





Federal police arrested the chief organizer of Rio's annual Carnival parade,
along with a federal judge and prosecutor, in a crackdown on illegal gaming
and money laundering Friday.

Google to buy DoubleClick for $3.1 billion

Friday afternoon.

SPORTS
 SI.com 








Ian Thomsen: Best and worst of the 2006-07 season





Thursday we submitted our official NBA awards ballots, but those results only
begin to explain what's gone on this season. Let's try to make further sense
of the last six months, shall we?





FULL STORY
















Phil Taylor: Robinson set an example of how to deal with racism





In many ways the 21st century sports world, with its round-the-clock cable
networks, Web site wise men and ceaseless talk-radio debates, would have been
unrecognizable to Jackie Robinson. He no doubt would have been amazed by the
sheer number of voices crashing into each other in our modern-day Babel, not
to mention their volume. But there is at least one thing that hasn't changed
in the 60 years since Robinson broke baseball's color barrier: The most
hateful loudmouths are the ones that seem to make themselves heard above the
din.

Dr. Gupta: The lessons I learned in 'Chasing Life'





When I began researching "Chasing Life" a year and a half ago, I wanted to
write a book about immortality. Futurists are envisioning a time when science
is able to beat death, and I was fascinated by what that would mean, both
physiologically and philosophically.

1st U.S. baby reportedly from frozen sperm, egg born





A California woman has given birth to the first baby conceived in the United
States by means of frozen sperm and a frozen egg, according to the fertility
firm that sponsored the study in which she took part.
